questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false about mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas?

options.a: It is lined by columnar epithelium
options.c: Identified histologically by the presence of ovarian-like stroma

questions.explanation:
Mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas is a premalignant condition. Mucinous cystadenoma or mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) is a benign tumor of the pancreas 
with high risk of malignancy. They are commonly seen in perimenopausal women, and about 855 
Sold by @itachibot two-thirds are located in the body or tail of the pancreas. MCNs are mostly incidental findings. When symptoms are present, they are usually nonspecific 
and include upper abdominal discomfort, early satiety, or weight loss. The cysts are lined by tall columnar epithelium. MCN's contain mucin-producing epithelium and 
are identified histologically by the presence of mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma. Staining 
for estrogen and progesterone is positive in most cases. Malignant transformation of MCN is common with large tumors and old patients. This is due to a 
stepwise accumulation of mutations (K-ras, p53). WHO classification of primar

questions.question:
Question 3: A 58-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent attacks of pancreatitis. An ERCP is done 
and it shows the presence of a fish-mouth sign at the ampulla of Vater. Which of the following 
statements is true about his condition?

options.a: It is more common in males
options.b: It only involves the main pancreatic duct
options.c: Head of pancreas is most common site of the neoplasm

questions.explanation:
856 
Sold by @itachibot A fish mouth sign at the ampulla of Vater during ERCP is indicative of intraductal papillary 
mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). It is most commonly seen in the head of the pancreas. The intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm can be diagnosed with the following findings 
(Ohashi triad) during endoscopy: • Bulging ampulla of Vater (fish-mouth sign) • Dilated pancreatic duct • Mucin secretion from the opening Equal distribution is seen between males and females in IPMN. Patients are usually in their 
seventh or eighth decade of life and present with abdominal pain or recurrent pancreatitis. This is 
caused by the obstruction of the pancreatic duct by thick mucin. Some patients have symptoms 
secondary to pancreatic insufficiencies like steatorrhea, diabetes, and weight loss. IMPNs are of three types: • Branch-duct IPMN (BD-IPMN) - affects only the small side branches. It is less frequently 
associated with malignancy. • Main duct IPMN (MD-IPMN) - Affects the main pancreatic duct. Malignant transformation is 
commonly seen. • Mixed-type IPMN - side-branch IPMNs that extend into the main duct

questions.question:
Question 4: 849 
Sold by @itachibot A 60-year-old man was incidentally found to have a pancreatic lesion on a USG. On further 
evaluation, a CT scan revealed the presence of a multicystic, lobulated mass in the pancreatic 
head, suggestive of serous cystadenoma. He is currently asymptomatic. What will be the next 
step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Endoscopic ultrasound-guided FNA (EUS-FNA) will be the next step in the management of this 
patient. Serous cystadenomas are essentially benign tumors without malignant potential. Serous 
cystadenocarcinoma has been reported very rarely (<1%). Therefore, malignant potential should 
not be a consideration for surgical resection. Surgical resection is done only for symptomatic 
patients. In asymptomatic patients, conservative management is adopted. However, it is important to 
confirm the diagnosis using EUS-FNA. It yields a non-viscous fluid with low CEA and amylase 
levels. Algorithm for management of pancreatic cystic neoplasms: 857 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: What is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers?
questions.explanation:
The activation of the K-ras 2 oncogene is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic 
cancers. It is activated in more than 95% of pancreatic cancers. Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) develops into pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma 
(PDAC) in a sequential pathway. A number of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes play a 
significant role in the pathogenesis of PDAC. They include: • K-ras 2 • PDX1 • CDKN2A/p16 • p53 • DPC4 (SMAD4) 858 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer?
questions.explanation:
An history of acute pancreatitis and female gender are not risk factors for the development of 
pancreatic cancer. Risk factors for pancreatic cancer: • Demographic factors: • Age (peak incidence, 65–75 years) • Male gender • Black ethnicity • Cigarette smoking • Genetic factors and medical conditions • Family history: • Two first-degree relatives with pancreas cancer • Germline BRCA2 mutations in some rare high-risk families • Hereditary pancreatitis • Chronic pancreatitis • Lynch syndrome • Ataxia telangiectasia • Peutz–Jeghers syndrome • Familial breast-ovarian cancer syndrome • Familial adenomatous polyposis • Diabetes mellitus 859 
Sold by @itachibot • Obesity

questions.question: Question 7: What is the most common type of pancreatic malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Ductal adenocarcinoma is the most common type of pancreatic cancer. Types of exocrine pancreatic cancer: • Ductal adenocarcinoma (85%) • Adenosquamous carcinoma • Acinar cell carcinoma Endocrine cancer of the pancreas is rare. They account for only 5% of clinically detected 
pancreatic tumours.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common site for pancreatic carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Pancreatic carcinomas arise most commonly from the head of the gland.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following statements is false regarding the presentation of patients with 
pancreatic carcinoma?

options.a: Release of platelet aggregating factors cause migratory thrombophlebitis
options.b: Abdominal pain is the most common presentation
options.c: Courvoisier's law implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas
options.d: Tumors of the body present at an advanced unresectable stage

questions.explanation:
Jaundice is the most common presentation of carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. It is 
secondary to obstruction of the distal bile duct. Clinical features of pancreatic cancers: • Jaundice (most common) • Nausea • Epigastric discomfort • Pruritus, dark urine, pale stools • Steatorrhea • Anorexia • Weight loss • Back pain - indicates retroperitoneal infiltration On examination, the patient can have: • Palpable abdominal mass • Ascites • Supraclavicular lymphnodes • Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign of malignancy) - due to release of 
platelet aggregating factors from the tumor 860 
Sold by @itachibot • Secondaries in the rectovesical pouch (Blumer’s shelf) • A palpable, non-tender gall bladder Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild 
jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. This sign implicates possible cancer of the head of 
the pancreas. Tumors of the body and tail of the gland often grow silently and present at an advanced 
unresectable stage. Image showing migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign of malignancy): Note: Trousseau's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. It indicates carpopedal spasm (finger and 
wrist spasm) after inflation of a blood pressure cuff for several minutes when the brachial artery is 
occluded.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is not true about pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma?

options.a: It is associated with desmoplastic changes, with scattering of neoplastic glands
options.d: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas causes obstruction of both the pancreatic and biliary

questions.explanation:
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas situated in the body of the pancreas are usually larger. Pancreatic adenocarcinomas are solid, slow-growing tumors, characterized by neoplastic tubular 
glands within a markedly desmoplastic fibrous stroma. They infiltrate locally, typically along 
nerve sheaths, along lymphatics, and into blood vessels. Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas causes obstruction of both the pancreatic and biliary ducts.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic pancreatitis presents with jaundice, severe 
itching, and weight loss. A smooth, globular mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant of 
the abdomen. You suspect pancreatic cancer. What will be the imaging modality of choice for 
the evaluation of the tumor?
questions.explanation:
Multidetector computed tomography (CT) is the imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of 
pancreatic tumors. It allows an accurate determination of the level of biliary obstruction, the 
relationship of the tumor to the blood vessels, and the presence of regional or metastatic disease. 861 
Sold by @itachibot For a detailed assessment of the luminal pancreato-biliary anatomy, MRCP should be considered. ERCP is reserved for cases requiring therapeutic or palliative intervention. It helps to perform a 
biopsy and to relieve obstruction by biliary stenting. The invasiveness of ERCP increases the rate 
of wound infection. Hence, it is not suitable for patients who will be undergoing surgery. F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) has the ability to differentiate 
between benign and malignant pancreas tumors. However, false-positive results are seen 
in FDG-PET. The benefits of FDG-PET over CT scans are yet to be determined. A CT-scan of pancreatic cancer:

Question 12: Which of the following is a radiological sign that is not seen in patients with adenocarcinoma 
of the pancreas?

options.d: Narrowing of C-loop of the duodenum

questions.explanation:
Widening of the C-loop of the duodenum is a barium meal finding seen in the adenocarcinoma of 
the pancreas. Radiological features of adenocarcinoma pancreas: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) findings: • Scrambled egg appearance • Double duct appearance Barium meal findings: • Inverse 3 sign • Rose thorning of 2nd part of the duodenum • Widened duodenal C-loop

questions.question: Question 13: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is:

options.a: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.explanation:
862 
Sold by @itachibot Transgastric or transduodenal FNAC or trucut biopsy performed under endoscopic ultrasound 
(EUS) guidance is the best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. This 
is because it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity. Endoscopic ultrasonography with a fine needle aspiration (EUS-FNA) is done if CT has failed to 
demonstrate a tumor. When a tissue diagnosis is required prior to surgery to distinguish between 
inflammation and neoplasia, EUS-FNA is helpful. Diagnostic laparoscopy prior to resection can spare an unnecessary laparotomy by identifying 
small peritoneal and liver metastases. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy of potentially resectable pancreatic tumors is avoided.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which is the most reliable tumor marker for the pre-treatment evaluation of a patient with 
pancreatic adenocarcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Carbohydrate antigen (CA) 19-9 is the most reliable tumor marker for pretreatment evaluation 
and post-treatment surveillance of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Other tumor markers for pancreatic carcinoma are carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and 
-fetoprotein.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of jaundice, clay-colored stools, and pruritis. 
After detailed radiological and pathological investigations, a 2 cm adenocarcinoma is found at 
the head of the pancreas. There is no spread to the adjacent structures. What is the preferred 
surgical management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Since there is no involvement of adjacent structures, the preferred surgical management in this 
patient is pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD), also known as Longmire–Traverso 
procedure. Pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD) involves the removal of: • Duodenum • Pancreatic head • The distal part of the bile duct The original pancreatoduodenectomy, as proposed by Whipple, included resection of the gastric 
antrum. Preserving the antrum and the pylorus results in a better physiological outcome, with no 
difference in survival or recurrence rates. Hence PPPD is preferred. For tumors of the body and tail, distal pancreatectomy is the preferred surgical management. Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (Beger's procedure) and Puestow's procedure 
(resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy) are management options for 
chronic pancreatitis.

questions.question:
Question 17: You assist in performing a Whipple procedure in a patient with carcinoma of the pancreas. All 
of the following structures will be resected in this surgery, except:
questions.explanation:
Whipple procedure does not involve the removal of the spleen and tail of the pancreas. The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the 
pancreas. It is done only in cases when: • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) • Tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus preserving pancreatoduodectomy The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure: • Distal stomach • Duodenum 864 
Sold by @itachibot • Proximal jejunum • Head of the pancreas • Gallbladder • Common bile duct (CBD) • Regional lymphatics

questions.question:
Question 18: During the reconstruction of the Whipple procedure, all of the following anastomoses will be 
done by a surgeon except:
questions.explanation:
Ileojejunostomy will not be done during the reconstruction of the Whipple procedure. The reconstruction following Whipple’s procedure or pylorus-preserving 
pancreaticoduodenectomy involves anastomosis in the following order: Pancreaticojejunostomy  Choledochojejunostomy  Gastrojejunostomy This is controversial since there is a difference in the reconstruction procedures mentioned in 
standard textbooks: Bailey and Love, 27th edition (Pg no: 1236) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + choledechojejunostomy + 
duodenojejunostomy Schwatrz, 11th edition (Pg no: 1493) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + choledechojejunostomy + 
gastrojejunostomy/duodenojejunostomy Sabiston, 20th edition (Pg no: 1546) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + hepaticojejunostomy + 
duodenojejunostomy 865 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: During the Whipple procedure, a surgeon performs the Kocher maneuver to access the 
retroperitoneum. This maneuver involves:

options.b: Mobilization of second part of duodenum

questions.explanation:
The Kocher maneuver involves the mobilization of the second part of the duodenum. It allows 
exposure of the retroperitoneal fat and the inferior vena cava (IVC). Another maneuver that is used to access the retroperitoneum is the Cattel Braasch maneuver. It 
involves the mobilization of the ascending colon. Other Kocher's in medicine: • Kocher's technique is used for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation. It involves four 
steps: Traction  External Rotation  Adduction  Medial Rotation (TEAM) • During thyroid palpation, Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the 
thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is false regarding complications of the Whipple procedure?

options.a: Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression
options.c: Any drainage output on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times normal value
options.d: Biliary leakage is the most common complication

questions.explanation:
Delayed gastric emptying is the most common complication following the Whipple procedure, not 
biliary leakage. Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression or 
the inability to tolerate oral intake. Most pancreatic fistulas are controlled by drainage catheters placed at the time of surgery. A 
pancreatic leak or pancreatic fistula is defined as the output via an intraoperatively placed drain 
(or percutaneous drain) of any measurable volume on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase 
>3 times the normal value. Other complications of the Whipple procedure include: 866 
Sold by @itachibot • Wound infection • Intra-abdominal abscess • Cardiac events • Bile leak • Overall reoperation • Exocrine insufficiency • Endocrine insufficiency

questions.question: Question 21: What is the most common cause of death in patients following pancreaticoduodenectomy?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of death following pancreaticoduodenectomy is sepsis due to 
anastomotic leakage. Anastomotic leakage is responsible for 33–88 % of postoperative deaths after 
pancreaticoduodenectomy. Only about 5–16 % of patients develop post-surgical bleeding 
complications.

Agents used in chemotherapy are: • Gemcitabine • Gemcitabine with capecitabine • Albumin bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel) • FOLFIRINOX - a combination of fluorouracil, irinotecan, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin However, there is only a 2–5 months increase in median survival with these regimens.
